commit_message:
Fix the parameter order of assertEqual in swiftclient test

On assertEqual, the order of parameters should be (expected, observed).
But, some part of swiftclient test were written with invalid order.
This patch fixes this problem.

Change-Id: I82b48b232b54bf88034dc40fedf27fc276c62ec3
Partially-bug: #1277104

commit_message:
debian: install cloud-init on Wheezy

cloud-init packages are not available in the Debian Wheezy repository.
However, they are available in wheezy-backports.

With this change, the cloud-init packages are installed from
wheezy-backports if DIB_RELEASE is wheezy.

Change-Id: I3daa3b0ba185ba3f7c1bf6b8f9b1f8c167fcb340
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/25/82325/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ADD_PACKAGES=sudo,adduser,locales,openssh-server,file,less,kbd,curl,rsync,bash-completion,linux-image-amd64 CLOUD_INIT_PACKAGES="cloud-init cloud-utils cloud-initramfs-growroot" if [ "$DIB_RELEASE" = "wheezy" ]; then sudo sh -c "echo deb $DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR wheezy-backports main >> ${TARGET_ROOT}/etc/apt/sources.list" sudo chroot ${TARGET_ROOT} apt-get update sudo chroot ${TARGET_ROOT} apt-get install -y -t wheezy-backports $CLOUD_INIT_PACKAGES else # unstable sudo chroot ${TARGET_ROOT} apt-get install -y $CLOUD_INIT_PACKAGES fi

commit_message:
Fix ceilometer.conf.sample mismatch

ceilometer.conf.sample mismatch issue makes the tests failing. This patch
removes the checkupdate.sh test from tox.ini, like it was removed from nova
too, until having a proper solution for handling the changes in
ceilometer.conf.sample, to fix the gate quickly.

Closes-Bug: #1297999

Change-Id: I7889580b3df2d30d80703d7ef540194e7f71ec51

commit_message:
Retry ceilometer-dbsync on failure

Some database services do not accept connections immediately
(cough*mongodb*cough) but take several seconds to finish initializing.
This commit will cause the ceilometer-dbsync to retry on failure in the
hopes that it is only a transient error.

Change-Id: I57d42fed5f2359011747bb764424383e05ad7ee1

commit_message:
Correct multi-line neutron attribute detection

The way that arrays were built-up for multi-line items caused the arrays
to become more tested with each element, making structures like
[[[a, b], c], d]

This corrects the behavior

Change-Id: I045abdfefd6f2cc85d0d9c70d3375fdce302f05d

commit_message:
Move change state to after storage calls

Instead of changing the state before we call
into storage, change it to after we get the
needed values from storage, this way if storage
fails (or has issues) the state will be left
unchanged.

This makes the storage calls preconditions for
a change state to occur (which seems to make
sense).

Change-Id: I78e107d6098b06fb42244ebfef1e5214746dc7fc

commit_message:
postgres incompatibility in InstanceGroup.get_hosts()

The original code fails in postgresql with:

"No operator matches the given name and argument type(s).
You might need to add explicit type casts."

It looks like the problem is that postgres doesn't do
implicit casts, so I changed the code to check a different column
that didn't require any.

Change-Id: I9342ec2bfbdd991d5f7a238eca59af003c7e7eac
Closes-bug: 1292963

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-25 17:03:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9b44cec141c4d8f4194c501a34142c6c5934652a', 'message': 'Add missing test for None in sqlalchemy query filter

In sqlalchemy a comparison against a non-null value will not match
null values, so the existing code at the end of
db.sqlalchemy.api.instance_get_all_by_filters() will not return
instances where vm_state is NULL.

This would be fine if the vm_state could never be null, but it
is declared as "nullable" in the Instance object. In many cases
"vm_state" will in fact have a value, but not all--in
get_test_instance() in test/utils.py the value of "vm_state" is not
specified.  There may be other similar cases.

Accordingly, this commit updates the test to explicitly check for None.

Closes-Bug: 1294756

Change-Id: I271cff22dec160fd0e76abadefd0fe06d32c3227

commit_message:
Add missing test for None in sqlalchemy query filter

In sqlalchemy a comparison against a non-null value will not match
null values, so the existing code at the end of
db.sqlalchemy.api.instance_get_all_by_filters() will not return
instances where vm_state is NULL.

This would be fine if the vm_state could never be null, but it
is declared as "nullable" in the Instance object. In many cases
"vm_state" will in fact have a value, but not all--in
get_test_instance() in test/utils.py the value of "vm_state" is not
specified.  There may be other similar cases.

Accordingly, this commit updates the test to explicitly check for None.

Without this fix the unit tests for bug 1292963 will fail because
the test instances have a vm_state of None.

Closes-Bug: 1294756
Related-Bug: 1292963
Change-Id: I271cff22dec160fd0e76abadefd0fe06d32c3227
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/82869/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove pip version specifier

We don't actually require pip 1.4, and saying that we do
breaks package installation in a lot of cases. Remove the
version specifier from our requirements list.

Fixes-bug: #1296310
Change-Id: I69c67c4c8cba7076e33292eaab9070ba51b4dff3

subject: Update tox.ini so flake8 works even without hacking
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-28 05:39:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/85202ff9b59b7735ee1eaa5ba7b11ba90b1061c8', 'message': 'Update tox.ini so flake8 works even without hacking

The flake8 command (when run from the command line or via vim-flake8) seems to
bypass the the normal pep8 [W]arning and [E]rror as well as py[F]lake checks
if the project level tox.ini includes a select, but doesn't include them in
it's select option (tested on flake8 v2.0 and v2.1).  Somehow if hacking is
installed these checks always run even if they're not explicitly listed in the
select list - but adding them so flake8 works on our project even without
hacking doesn't seem to cause any problems.

Also The [flake8] section's "select" option in tox.ini doesn't seem to run all
checks when presented with the space-comma seperated list.  I had to pull out
the bare except check (H201), because our hacking fix for the "H201 # noqa"
hasn't been released to pypi yet (maybe hacking version 0.9.0?).

As far as I know the Swift core development team is fully onboard with pep8,
and the flake8 checks are mostly like "unused import" stuff - so I *think*
this change is more about making the tool test what we want it too and not
changing or adding any new requirements or expectations.

commit_message:
Update tox.ini so flake8 works even without hacking

The flake8 command (when run from the command line or via vim-flake8) seems to
bypass the the normal pep8 [W]arning and [E]rror as well as py[F]lake checks
if the project level tox.ini includes a select, but doesn't include them in
it's select option (tested on flake8 v2.0 and v2.1).  Somehow if hacking is
installed these checks always run even if they're not explicitly listed in the
select list - but adding them so flake8 works on our project even without
hacking doesn't seem to cause any problems.

Also The [flake8] section's "select" option in tox.ini doesn't seem to run all
checks when presented with the space-comma seperated list.  I had to pull out
the bare except check (H201), because our hacking fix for the "H201 # noqa"
hasn't been released to pypi yet (maybe hacking version 0.9.0?).

As far as I know the Swift core development team is fully onboard with pep8,
and the flake8 checks are mostly like "unused import" stuff - so I *think*
this change is more about making the tool test what we want it too and not
changing or adding any new requirements or expectations.

Change-Id: Ia911c63745100cce182d5c5eb67b77e31c1e9b18

commit_message:
Support binding:vif_security parameter in neutron

Configure filtering rule based on port binding configration
in neturon. nova can say to libvirt which type of spoofing (ip, mac,
dhcp) should be used.

Fixes creation of qbr bridge and veth pairs on neutron demands by
passing require_iptables.

Change-Id: I704a49cebe3153d070a3d39c9ad090f04472753a
Closes-Bug: #1112912

commit_message:
Remove test for obsolated port_filter on Neutron

Neutron security group is broken now. In order to fix it,
Neutron must send vif plugging related parameters to nova.
However exisiting port_filter attribute is insufficient for this
purpose, so we need to obsolate port_filter attribute.
(See discussion in the related bug #1112912)
This is a patch for Neturon
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21946/
This is a patch for Nova
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/44596/

In this commit, we need to remove tempest test for
obsolated port_filter attribute.

Change-Id: I66c6ab991624989d3213dbda17a90fa6da85e5b1
Related-bug: #1112912

subject: Fix spurious warning in pipeline check
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-07 07:51:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift/commit/47838043f2f969b55560594b14096d7c8e944db7', 'message': "Fix spurios warning in pipeline check

The storage::server class includes a bit of logic that checks
the pipeline and warns if ${type}-server isn't included.
However, the check has a logic flaw such that if $pipeline is an
array and contains ${type}-server, the warning is triggered
anyway.  This patch corrects the bad logic so that the warning
isn't triggered spuriously.

Change-Id: I7f81598f2f7910a2175fe772c9d82b2a1067826c
Closes-Bug: #1289187
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-03-07 07:53:25.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/storage/server.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift/commit/01a3a40bcc43ffd492bea87e9b7b143bedccec37', 'message': "Fix spurious warning in pipeline check

The storage::server class includes a bit of logic that checks
the pipeline and warns if ${type}-server isn't included.
However, the check has a logic flaw such that if $pipeline is an
array and contains ${type}-server, the warning is triggered
anyway.  This patch corrects the bad logic so that the warning
isn't triggered spuriously.

Change-Id: I7f81598f2f7910a2175fe772c9d82b2a1067826c
Closes-Bug: #1289187
"}]
commit_message:
Fix spurious warning in pipeline check

The storage::server class includes a bit of logic that checks
the pipeline and warns if ${type}-server isn't included.
However, the check has a logic flaw such that if $pipeline is an
array and contains ${type}-server, the warning is triggered
anyway.  This patch corrects the bad logic so that the warning
isn't triggered spuriously.

Change-Id: I7f81598f2f7910a2175fe772c9d82b2a1067826c
Closes-Bug: #1289187
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift refs/changes/88/78888/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Warn if ${type-server} isn't included in the pipeline if is_array($pipeline) { if !member($pipeline, "${type}-server") { } } elsif $pipeline != "${type}-server" { warning("swift storage server ${type} must specify ${type}-server")
deleted_lines: # TODO if array does not include type-server, warn if( (is_array($pipeline) and ! member($pipeline, "${type}-server")) or $pipeline != "${type}-server" ) {

commit_message:
Revert "Port to oslo.messaging"

This reverts commit bcd9f363ff8a10ff30795c54f471a8c6d76450fe

Sorry, but this is just getting kinda silly at this point.  We have one thing after another popping up around this and given where we're at in the release stage I'm not willing to accept any more risk on this.
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/70/81870/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.openstack.common import rpc orig_rpc_call = rpc.call def rpc_call_wrapper(context, topic, msg, timeout=None): return orig_rpc_call(context, topic, msg) self.stubs.Set(rpc, 'call', rpc_call_wrapper)

subject: Add Storage Policy Support to Account HEAD
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-15 00:27:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/4eb335e9ef5f5cfaa52b152164afaafad7f34941', 'message': 'Add Storage Policy Support to Account HEAD

This change updates the account HEAD handler to report out per
policy object and byte usage for the account.  Cumulative values
are still reported and policy names are used in the report
out (unless request is sent to an account server directly in
which case policy indexes are used for easier accounting).

Below is an example of the relevant HEAD response for a cluster
with 3 policies and just a few small objects:

   X-Account-Container-Count: 3
   X-Account-Object-Count: 3
   X-Account-Bytes-Used: 21
   X-Storage-Policy-Object-Count-Bronze: 1
   X-Storage-Policy-Bytes-Used-Bronze: 7
   X-Storage-Policy-Object-Count-Silver: 1
   X-Storage-Policy-Bytes-Used-Silver: 7
   X-Storage-Policy-Object-Count-Gold: 1
   X-Storage-Policy-Bytes-Used-Gold: 7

Change-Id: I5ec251f9a8014dd89764340de927d09466c72221
Implements: blueprint storage-policies

commit_message:
Add Storage Policy Support to Account HEAD

This change updates the account HEAD handler to report out per
policy object and byte usage for the account.  Cumulative values
are still reported and policy names are used in the report
out (unless request is sent to an account server directly in
which case policy indexes are used for easier accounting).

Below is an example of the relevant HEAD response for a cluster
with 3 policies and just a few small objects:

   X-Account-Container-Count: 3
   X-Account-Object-Count: 3
   X-Account-Bytes-Used: 21
   X-Storage-Policy-Bronze-Object-Count: 1
   X-Storage-Policy-Bronze-Bytes-Used: 7
   X-Storage-Policy-Silver-Object-Count: 1
   X-Storage-Policy-Silver-Bytes-Used: 7
   X-Storage-Policy-Gold-Object-Count: 1
   X-Storage-Policy-Gold-Bytes-Used: 7

Change-Id: I5ec251f9a8014dd89764340de927d09466c72221
Implements: blueprint storage-policies
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/47/73747/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # if any policy index related headers are present in resp headers, # replace them here with the friendly policy name if [header for header in res.headers if POLICY in header]: key_bytes_base = POLICY + '-' + 'Bytes-Used' + '-' key_objects_base = POLICY + '-' + 'Object-Count' + '-' new_headers = res.headers.copy() for resp in res.headers: # replace raw policy index if resp == POLICY_INDEX: new_headers[POLICY] = \ POLICIES.get_by_index(res.headers[POLICY_INDEX]).name del new_headers[POLICY_INDEX] # replace account HEAD byte and object counts if resp.startswith(key_bytes_base): new_headers[key_bytes_base + POLICIES.get_by_index( resp[resp.rfind('-') + 1:]).name] = res.headers[resp] del new_headers[resp] if resp.startswith(key_objects_base): new_headers[key_objects_base + POLICIES.get_by_index( resp[resp.rfind('-') + 1:]).name] = res.headers[resp] del new_headers[resp] res.headers = new_headers.copy()
deleted_lines: # if a policy index is present in resp headers, replace it here # with the friendly policy name if POLICY_INDEX in res.headers: res.headers[POLICY] = \ POLICIES.get_by_index(res.headers[POLICY_INDEX]).name del res.headers[POLICY_INDEX]

subject: Provide a new ComputeManager for Ironic
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-24 22:32:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/23f0cad0c768ffb6ca2ae0af91e57b27ef5969bd', 'message': "Provide a new ComputeManager for Ironic.

Ironic is internally clustered and that causes some friction
with Nova which assumes that each n-cpu instance is the only
one responsible for any given VM. While this is going to be
addressed in the long term, at the moment we need to make
it possible to run in an HA setup for Ironic.

The short term solution proposed is to run 2+ nova-compute's
each of which reports the same hostname (e.g. ironic). This
works but has some caveats - one of which is that _init_instance
will now race between different nova-compute instances starting
up at the same time. A custom ComputeManager permits us to address
that without prejuidice to future long term solutions.

Relatedly, TripleO needs Ironic to permit service startup before
keystone is initialised, which the removal of API calls during
init_host permits - and as there are no API calls needed for
correct behaviour of the Ironic driver, this is straight forward :).

See https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/ironic-nova-friction for
more discussion.

Change-Id: I68d46c4da8715df03c3a88393b55665dc57045a3
Closes-Bug: #1295503

commit_message:
Provide a new ComputeManager for Ironic

Ironic is internally clustered and that causes some friction
with Nova which assumes that each n-cpu instance is the only
one responsible for any given VM. While this is going to be
addressed in the long term, at the moment we need to make
it possible to run in an HA setup for Ironic.

The short term solution proposed is to run 2+ nova-compute's
each of which reports the same hostname (e.g. ironic). This
works but has some caveats - one of which is that _init_instance
will now race between different nova-compute instances starting
up at the same time. A custom ComputeManager permits us to address
that without prejuidice to future long term solutions.

Relatedly, TripleO needs Ironic to permit service startup before
keystone is initialised, which the removal of API calls during
init_host permits - and as there are no API calls needed for
correct behaviour of the Ironic driver, this is straight forward :).

See https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/ironic-nova-friction for
more discussion.

Change-Id: I68d46c4da8715df03c3a88393b55665dc57045a3
Closes-Bug: #1295503

added_lines: # coding=utf-8 # # Copyright 2014 Red Hat, Inc. # Copyright 2013 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Short term workaround for friction in the Nova compute manager with Ironic. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/ironic-nova-friction contains current design work. The goal here is to generalise the areas where n-c talking to a clustered hypervisor has issues, and long term fold them into the main ComputeManager. """ from nova.compute import manager class ClusteredComputeManager(manager.ComputeManager): def init_host(self): """Initialization for a clustered compute service.""" self.driver.init_host(host=self.host) context = nova.context.get_admin_context() instances = instance_obj.InstanceList.get_by_host( context, self.host, expected_attrs=['info_cache']) # defer_iptables_apply is moot for clusters - no local iptables # if CONF.defer_iptables_apply: # self.driver.filter_defer_apply_on() self.init_virt_events() try: # evacuation is moot for a clustered hypervisor # # checking that instance was not already evacuated to other host # self._destroy_evacuated_instances(context) # Don't run _init_instance until we solve the partitioning problem # - with N n-cpu's all claiming the same hostname, running # _init_instance here would lead to race conditions where each runs # _init_instance concurrently. # for instance in instances: # self._init_instance(context, instance) pass finally: # defer_iptables_apply is moot for clusters - no local iptables # if CONF.defer_iptables_apply: # self.driver.filter_defer_apply_off() pass

commit_message:
Fix PUT to existing container w/o specific storage policy

This also introduces the storage_policy_index property on the broker.

commit_message:
Release 3.2.0

Updated Modulefile and README.md for 3.2.0 release.

Change-Id: Ic1be6d1227236ece62adc148b7a1cd83a1b14bac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/83/83183/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: **3.2.0** * Replace pip with native package manager for VMWare. * Deprecated logdir parameter in favor of log_dir. * Allows log_dir to be set to false in order to disable file logging. * Enables libvirt at boot. * Adds RBD backend support for VM image storage. * Parameterizes libvirt cpu_mode and disk_cachemodes. * Adds support for https auth endpoints. * Adds ability to disable installation of nova utilities.

commit_message:
Bump up sleep when expecting a timeout

It seemed like some of the tests ment to exercise the proxy's timeout could
would occastionally race and the backend mock would be able to cough up a
chunk before the timeout fired in the proxy - typically resulting in a failed
assertion like " lalala" != 'lalala'.

We paramaterize the timeout value, and bump it up for those cases where we are
expecting to hit the timeout.  Timing shows this change is just as fast for
passing tests.  And if you want to break the node_timeout in
proxy.controller.base you can verify the tests are still just as effective -
if a bit slower to detect the failure path.

Fixes bug #1272509

Change-Id: Iaf91d9d551e94fc317a08e8c0ee02daeed331b60

commit_message:
Remove backwards compatability in setup-baremetal

TripleO CI now populates the nodes array in the JSON datafile, so the
backward compatability code in setup-baremetal can be removed.

As an added bonus, nodes that specify more than one MAC address will
have all of them registered with nova-bm.

Change-Id: I7b8e7b67694319e377df400b122f16bff9e15370
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/67/78467/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo " --nodes -- JSON list of nodes to register"JSON_PATH="" TEMP=`getopt -o h -l help,service-host:,nodes: -n $SCRIPT_NAME -- "$@"` --nodes) JSON_PATH="$2"; shift 2 ;;if [ -z "$JSON_PATH" ]; then echo "A node list is required."register-nodes $SERVICE_HOST <(cat $JSON_PATH)
deleted_lines: echo "For backwards compatibility a testenv data file may also be" echo "supplied as the first non-option argument, but this will be removed" echo "once tripleo-CI is updated." echo echo "One of --first and --not-first is required." echo echo " --first -- only select the first node" echo " --not-first -- select all but the first node"NODE_SELECTION=0 TEMP=`getopt -o h -l help,service-host:,first,not-first -n $SCRIPT_NAME -- "$@"` --first) NODE_SELECTION=1 ; shift ;; --not-first) NODE_SELECTION=-1 ; shift ;;BACKWARDS_COMPAT=${1:-''}if [ $NODE_SELECTION -eq 0 ]; then echo "One of --first or --not-first is required."if [ -n "$BACKWARDS_COMPAT" ]; then # We have a backwards compat file, but we might have a new testenv - probe # to see. PROBE=$(jq -r '.nodes[0].cpu' $BACKWARDS_COMPAT) if [ "$PROBE" = "null" ]; then # No CPU data in the first node (may imply no first node..) so assume # we're working with a older CI testenv. # In that environment we use the environment variables CPU=$NODE_CPU MEM=$NODE_MEM DISK=$NODE_DISK ARCH=$NODE_ARCH # Plus MAC addresses and PM from the whole testenv file. if [ $NODE_SELECTION -eq 1 ]; then FIELDS="1" elif [ $NODE_SELECTION -eq -1 ]; then FIELDS="2-" fi MACS=$(OS_CONFIG_FILES=$BACKWARDS_COMPAT os-apply-config --key node-macs --type raw | cut -d' ' -f$FIELDS) PM_IPS=$(OS_CONFIG_FILES=$BACKWARDS_COMPAT os-apply-config --key node-pm-ips --type raw --key-default '' | cut -d' ' -f$FIELDS) PM_USERS=$(OS_CONFIG_FILES=$BACKWARDS_COMPAT os-apply-config --key node-pm-users --type raw --key-default '' | cut -d' ' -f$FIELDS) PM_PASSWORDS=$(OS_CONFIG_FILES=$BACKWARDS_COMPAT os-apply-config --key node-pm-passwords --type raw --key-default '' | cut -d' ' -f$FIELDS) MODE="legacy" else MODE="new" fi else echo "A test environment file is required." exit 1 fi echo $MODE if [ "new" = "$MODE" ]; then if [ $NODE_SELECTION -eq 1 ]; then NODES=$(jq '[.nodes[0]]' $BACKWARDS_COMPAT) elif [ $NODE_SELECTION -eq -1 ]; then NODES=$(jq '.nodes - [.nodes[0]]' $BACKWARDS_COMPAT) fi # Backwards compat until we fix register-nodes / subsume it / whatever. # At that point heterogeneous node support becomes trivial. CPU=$(jq -r '.[0].cpu' <<< $NODES) MEM=$(jq -r '.[0].memory' <<< $NODES) DISK=$(jq -r '.[0].disk' <<< $NODES) ARCH=$(jq -r '.[0].arch' <<< $NODES) # Note: this takes only the first MAC - another legacy limit until we # refactor register-nodes. MACS=$(jq -r '.[] | .mac[0]' <<< $NODES) PM_IPS=$(jq -r '.[] | .pm_addr' <<< $NODES) PM_USERS=$(jq -r '.[] | .pm_user' <<< $NODES) PM_PASSWORDS=$(jq -r '.[] | .pm_password' <<< $NODES) fi # After we delete the backwards compat mode, register-nodes should have it's # interface changed to just take the node vector - collapsing this script down # to: # register-nodes # setup flavors # register deploy ramdisk register-nodes $CPU $MEM $DISK "$MACS" $SERVICE_HOST "$PM_IPS" "$PM_USERS" "$PM_PASSWORDS" deploy_kernel=$TRIPLEO_ROOT/deploy-ramdisk.kernel deploy_ramdisk=$TRIPLEO_ROOT/deploy-ramdisk.initramfs deploy_kernel_id=$(glance image-create --name bm-deploy-kernel --public \ --disk-format aki < "$deploy_kernel" | awk ' / id / {print $4}') deploy_ramdisk_id=$(glance image-create --name bm-deploy-ramdisk --public \ --disk-format ari < "$deploy_ramdisk" | awk ' / id / {print $4}') function cleanup_flavor () { local FLAVOR_NAME=${1:?"cleanup_flavor requires a flavor name"} if nova flavor-show "$FLAVOR_NAME" &> /dev/null; then nova flavor-delete "$FLAVOR_NAME" fi } # While we can't mix hypervisors, having non-baremetal flavors will just # confuse things. cleanup_flavor 'm1.tiny' cleanup_flavor 'm1.small' cleanup_flavor 'm1.medium' cleanup_flavor 'm1.large' cleanup_flavor 'm1.xlarge' cleanup_flavor 'baremetal' # XXX(lifeless) this should be a loop making sure every node is represented # with a flavor. nova flavor-create baremetal auto $MEM $DISK $CPU nova flavor-key baremetal set "cpu_arch"="$ARCH" \ "baremetal:deploy_kernel_id"="$deploy_kernel_id" \ "baremetal:deploy_ramdisk_id"="$deploy_ramdisk_id"

commit_message:
Add 'methods' to all v3 test tokens

methods is a required field of v3 tokens but none of the sample tokens
have them. This field is required for determining the difference between
a v2 and a v3 AccessInfo object.

Change-Id: I4d45e90f24eeb2f35451549771ad999628619c20

Neutron config-ref update

Import new configuration options.

Add the ml2_mlnx table for the Mellanox ML2 mechanism.

Change-Id: Ieda52223360ac452a9741894e2a4f505d9c33a71
Closes-Bug: #1297827

commit_message:
Full support for Keystone LDAP integration

Adding full support for integrating Keystone via LDAP. Enables
support for managing all LDAP related Keystone options.

 - Add two examples of LDAP configuration, although LDAP environments
   are highly variable, these will help get everyone started
 - Modify the keystone::ldap class to support all LDAP related options
 - Check sane defaults in the keystone::ldap class to hopefully reduce mistakes
 - Add a dependency on the python-ldap package
 - Modify the LDAP test to match the new class
 - Make the default-tenant optional since some LDAP backends do not
   support this

Change-Id: Ie6879eb4816fd2b906f72cac8deb3b62bd4b2430
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/56/82856/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: newparam(:ignore_default_tenant, :boolean => true) do newvalues(:true, :false) defaultto false end

commit_message:
Fix account/container logging mismatch

This change makes account and container servers log the same.

The order for both is now "content-type, referrer, txid, user-agent".

Change-Id: I54ce242705cd75822b8974fecad4e890a2d961ce
Closes-Bug: 1280955

commit_message:
Release 3.1.0

Updated README.md and Modulefile for release 3.1.0

Change-Id: I4339212ec8677ac2c32fd51da8375ef195d59ad3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/70/83170/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: **3.1.0** * Added VXLAN support. * Configures security group when using ML2 plugin. * Ensures installation of ML2 plugin. * Fixed server deprecated warnings. * Tuned report and downtime intervals for l2 agent. * Added support for neutron nvp plugin. * Ensures linuxbridge dependency is installed on RHEL. * Improved L3 scheduler support. * Fixed improper test for tunnel_types param. * Allows log_dir to be set to false in order to disable file logging. * Improves consistency with other puppet modules for OpenStack by prefixing database related parameters with database. * Removed strict checks for vlan_ranges. * Fixed neutron-metering-agent package for Ubuntu. * Fixed VPNaaS service name for Ubuntu. * Fixed FWaaS race condition. * Fixed ML2 package dependency for Ubuntu. * Removed erronious check for service_plugins. * Added support for https auth endpoints. * Makes haproxy package management optional.

subject: Use updated request_id middleware
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-14 05:10:13.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/openstack/common/middleware/request_id.py', 'cinder/api/openstack/wsgi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/0553ecdb1ef94ecc6f71bb3245968daa7669f199', 'message': 'Use updated request_id middleware

The request_id middleware from oslo had a bug that would cause it to
sometimes use the wrong value for the x-openstack-request-id response
header when handling multiple requests. The fix for this bug changed
how the middleware operates, and it is now responsibility of the
application to attach the header.

This change syncs the updated middleware and includes the alterations
necessary to use it.

Closes-bug: 1289696
Change-Id: Ifdee53cfcf41f29071e86df7b174ac2f091039da
'}]
commit_message:
Use updated request_id middleware

The request_id middleware from oslo had a bug that would cause it to
sometimes use the wrong value for the x-openstack-request-id response
header when handling multiple requests. The fix for this bug changed
how the middleware operates, and it is now responsibility of the
application to attach the header.

This change syncs the updated middleware and includes the alterations
necessary to use it.

Closes-bug: 1289696
Change-Id: Ifdee53cfcf41f29071e86df7b174ac2f091039da
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/82/80482/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.openstack.common.middleware import request_id # NOTE(hdd): compute-request-id should disappear in a later API version headers[request_id.HTTP_RESP_HEADER_REQUEST_ID] = context.request_id

commit_message:
Make bin/swift testable part 1

To make bin/swift importable for testing it needs to be renamed/moved.
The final idea is to move it to swiftclient/shell.py and add only a stub
in bin/swift to import swiftclient/shell.py.

However, doing this in a single step makes reviewing very hard, because
now there are > 1400 lines deleted from bin/swift and added to
swiftclient/shell.py - Gerrit doesn't detect the moved file.

For example: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/73710/2/

This patch first moves the code to swiftclient/shell.py and uses
setup.py/cfg to create the stub file in bin/swift. A follow up
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/76489/) will then add the stub itself
in bin/swift (and remove the entry in setup.py).

The change to tox.ini is related to bug 1290562 and can be removed in
the future.

Change-Id: Id86392ccaf09e1d80a5d808fb49827d6d18c2588
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/87/76487/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [entry_points] console_scripts = swift = swiftclient.shell:main

subject: Re-work how debugger CLI opts are registered
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-18 08:16:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/774709188e5ca7cd1b56904c128591c57d923401', 'message': "Re-work how debugger CLI opts are registered

CLI options must be registered before the command line is parsed or a
cfg.ArgsAlreadyParsedError is raised.

Since commit 2cbea24 we are registering two 'remote_debug' arguments
in nova.service. In commit b506529, we see a hack being added to
ensure that nova.service is imported and the CLI opts registered
before config.parse_args() is called.

To clean this up somewhat, refactor all the elements of this remote
debugger support into nova.debugger. Avoid importing modules at
module import time since we need to import this before monkey
patching. Add a function for registering the CLI options just before
config.parse_args() is called. And fail gracefully if the CLI options
aren't registered when we called debugger.init().

Note that because the options aren't registered at module import time
any more, the config generator doesn't pick them up. However, that's
actually a good thing since this support doesn't work if you enable it
via config files since debugger.enabled() only looks at the command
line.

Change-Id: I97f747a2fb9222137203657df1d86ba89f3219e2

commit_message:
Re-work how debugger CLI opts are registered

CLI options must be registered before the command line is parsed or a
cfg.ArgsAlreadyParsedError is raised.

Since commit 2cbea24 we are registering two 'remote_debug' arguments
in nova.service. In commit b506529, we see a hack being added to
ensure that nova.service is imported and the CLI opts registered
before config.parse_args() is called.

To clean this up somewhat, refactor all the elements of this remote
debugger support into nova.debugger. Avoid importing modules at
module import time since we need to import this before monkey
patching. Add a function for registering the CLI options just before
config.parse_args() is called. And fail gracefully if the CLI options
aren't registered when we called debugger.init().

Note that because the options aren't registered at module import time
any more, the config generator doesn't pick them up. However, that's
actually a good thing since this support doesn't work if you enable it
via config files since debugger.enabled() only looks at the command
line.

DocImpact: remote_debug options are not available via the config file,
only via the command line.

Change-Id: I97f747a2fb9222137203657df1d86ba89f3219e2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/86/74286/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import debugger debugger.register_cli_opts()

Open Juno development

Bump preversion to 2014.2 to formally open Juno development.
The Icehouse release branch (milestone-proposed) will be cut
from the last commit before this one.

subject: Fix envutils.get_global (prev. default_deployment_id) errors management
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-17 13:54:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/a1adfafe65a7add5b5f62eedfa34754ebb45c067', 'message': "Fix envutils.get_global (prev. default_deployment_id) errors management

* Since envutils.get_global doesn't raise anymore 'InvalidArgumentsException'
(due to this fix https://launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1291298) we are encountering
issues when get_global simply returns None. That's why the bool parameter
doRaise was added to get_global, so when needed the method will raise
'InvalidArgumentsException' and in the case of #1291298 get_global won't raise
any exception and will simply return None.
* Fixed unit test of Tempest Install command, deploy_id was always None in the
unit test and once the above modification applied, an InvalidArgumentsException
was raised which caused the failing of the test.

Change-Id: I18e2ac99e6412c3ae67769390e390d4210243381
Closes-Bug: #1293454
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-03-17 17:40:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/858eda45fdcce3ef79ca7c267f6bb06273ebe49f', 'message': "Fix envutils.get_global (prev. default_deployment_id) errors management

Closes-Bug: #1293454

* Since envutils.get_global doesn't raise anymore 'InvalidArgumentsException'

issues when get_global simply returns None. That's why the bool parameter
doRaise was added to get_global, so when needed the method will raise

unit test and once the above modification applied, an InvalidArgumentsException
was raised which caused the failing of the test.

Change-Id: I18e2ac99e6412c3ae67769390e390d4210243381
Closes-Bug: #1293454

commit_message:
Fix envutils.get_global (prev. default_deployment_id) errors management

* Since envutils.get_global doesn't raise anymore 'InvalidArgumentsException'
(due to this fix https://launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1291298) we are encountering
issues when get_global simply returns None. That's why the bool parameter
doRaise was added to get_global, so when needed the method will raise
'InvalidArgumentsException' and in the case of #1291298 get_global won't raise
any exception and will simply return None.
* Fixed unit test of Tempest Install command, deploy_id was always None in the
unit test and once the above modification applied, an InvalidArgumentsException
was raised which caused the failing of the test.

Change-Id: I18e2ac99e6412c3ae67769390e390d4210243381
Closes-Bug: #1293454
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/74/80974/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuid deploy_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) self.tempest_commands.install(deploy_id)

commit_message:
NSX: Sync do not pass around model object

The NSX sync backend previously passed around a sqlalchemy model object
around which was nice because we did not need to query the database an
additional time to update the status of an object.

Unfortunately, this was add done within a db transaction which included a
call to NSX which could cause deadlock this needed to be removed. Now a
dict is passed around instead and proper transaction handling
is used when updating objects.

Closes-bug: #1281772

Conflicts:
	neutron/plugins/nicira/common/sync.py

Change-Id: Id50abd8f2143b127d1ca81c360c1c6d400e1d74f
(cherry picked from commit 084b7f62280241a9037b6f9e592c466135e5fec1)

commit_message:
NSX: Fix possible deadlock in sync code

This patch removes the call to nsx from within the db transcation
which can cause deadlock if another request comes in during this time.

Closes-bug: #1278991
Change-Id: If16b53a77997bccfdff2554dead26f42e23eaec9
(cherry picked from commit d59d5a1c72c2324b857225680f5578d381a2ec73)

commit_message:
be extra explicit for people reading logs

people seem to be confused by gate_hook failed, even though 5 lines
above we say running gate_hook. Make it extra explicit what to do
next.

Change-Id: I19d77b905c61311c0c68e23ed67f137df682cf34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/71/83071/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo "ERROR: gate_hook failed - exit code: $GATE_RETVAL" echo " please look at the relevant log files to determine the root cause"

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-24 13:00:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/d3a82310b54bf17a1f1b3dc674eb2a7e0b02df38', 'message': 'Use OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH as ZUUL_BRANCH when defined

Attempting to prevent trove installation on the
 stable/havana postgresql gate.

Change-Id: Id49f9730a2feeca51dee057d5aec6968a9f62bb3
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-03-24 13:17:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/44676f3170050d3a03c87debc6d6badc094726a8', 'message': 'Use OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH as ZUUL_BRANCH when defined

Attempting to prevent trove installation on the
 stable/havana postgresql gate.

Change-Id: Id49f9730a2feeca51dee057d5aec6968a9f62bb3
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-03-24 15:13:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/6930a510b4b5fb8f345818af3904e42d1904842f', 'message': "Use OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH as ZUUL_BRANCH when defined

When a change on master branch triggered a stable job,
the stable job's localrc configured according to the
master rules instead of the stable rules.

For example: The stable/havana job on the devstack-gate changes
attempted to install trove, which was not part of the integrated
set at the havana time.
It is also caused failures on the stable/havana postgresql jobs.

We saw similar issues on the periodic jobs as well.

The issue can be solved by using the OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH, instead of
ZUUL_BRANCH in the above cases.

Change-Id: Id49f9730a2feeca51dee057d5aec6968a9f62bb3
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-03-25 10:43:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/9c64a4ff1946e58a122f2d6c622498914e0f97c7', 'message': "Use OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH in devstack-vm-gate.sh

When a change on master branch triggered a stable job,
the stable job's localrc configured according to the
master rules instead of the stable rules.

For example: The stable/havana job on the devstack-gate changes
attempted to install trove, which was not part of the integrated

devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh always defines the OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH.

commit_message:
Use OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH in devstack-vm-gate.sh

When a change on master branch triggered a stable job,
the stable job's localrc configured according to the
master rules instead of the stable rules.

For example: The stable/havana job on the devstack-gate changes
attempted to install trove, which was not part of the integrated
set at the havana time.
It is also caused failures on the stable/havana postgresql jobs.

We saw similar issues on the periodic jobs as well.

The issue can be solved by using the OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH, instead of
ZUUL_BRANCH.

devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh always defines the OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH.

Change-Id: Id49f9730a2feeca51dee057d5aec6968a9f62bb3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/96/82496/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export ZUUL_BRANCH=${OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH}

commit_message:
Enable lazy translations in httpd/keystone.py

This allows strings being returned in an HTTP response to be translated
into the language specified in the HTTP requests headers.

Closes-bug: #1297922
Change-Id: I8a671277f861075deddd1ee4cf5daca62a43fff7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/13/83113/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.openstack.common import gettextutils # NOTE(dstanek): gettextutils.enable_lazy() must be called before # gettextutils._() is called to ensure it has the desired lazy lookup # behavior. This includes cases, like keystone.exceptions, where # gettextutils._() is called at import time. gettextutils.enable_lazy()

commit_message:
Adds to Keystone to convert V2 endpoints to V3

The Domain Quota Management Driver uses the V3 Authentication Token.
Also, it tries to contact Keystone for getting list of projects in a
domain using V3 API like /v3/projects?domain_id=<id>. But the
keystone v3/client.py default uses V2 API and hence code changed
to convert V2 endpoints for V3 endpoints. This change is required
to implement blue print domain-quota-driver-api

Change-Id: If62ffc5e5252477bbe4d80f14c0a7653e11d5403
Closes-Bug: 1260916

commit_message:
4.1.1 Fixed issue with parrallel tests execution

When user runs several types of OSTF tests, these tests can be run
in parallel and in the result tearDown method deletes all environment
and some tests will fail. To avoid this we will generate new name
for each new environment and we should also delete only this environment
in tearDown method.

Change-Id: I12f1e797eceefe11dda50ab61aabe15ab9036931
Closes-Bug: #1285562

commit_message:
Enforce alphabetical ordering of element-deps

We've started to require this in reviews, so we should really have
automation in place to catch it right away.

Change-Id: I43fd90647acba400cea11c665fb587856514b0ee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/36/81636/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Check alphabetical ordering of element-deps if [ $(basename $i) = "element-deps" ]; then UNSORTED=${TMPDIR}/element-deps.unsorted SORTED=${TMPDIR}/element-deps.sorted grep -v '^#' $i > ${UNSORTED} sort ${UNSORTED} > ${SORTED} diff -c ${UNSORTED} ${SORTED} if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then echo "ERROR: $i is not sorted alphabetically" rc=1 fi fi

commit_message:
Add dib-lint script

This will provide a place to put checks that catch common errors
in elements.  To start, this just checks that files starting with
a shebang are chmod +x so they can actually be run.

Change-Id: I4116a8f38f7bdfc5866764354c459fad8ca18e92

commit_message:
Consolidate keystone token_flush setup into one command.

Obsolete need for editor knowledge by allowing for easy copy and
paste of one command that can be used to set this up.

Change-Id: I21b31ebd52a88949aaac758d5f7f17b7ff8839ba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/73/82973/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Run the following command to purge expired tokens every <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>crontab -l | grep -q token_flush \ echo '@hourly /usr/bin/keystone-manage token_flush >/var/log/keystone/keystone-tokenflush.log 2>&1' >> /var/spool/cron/root</userinput></screen>
deleted_lines: <para>Edit the crontab for the root user:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>crontab -e</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Add the following line to purge expired tokens every </para> <programlisting>@hourly /usr/bin/keystone-manage token_flush >/var/log/keystone/keystone-tokenflush.log 2>&1</programlisting>

commit_message:
Remove unused file addmethod.openstackapi

This file is just a very ugly copy from cinder without proper DocBook
markup and not used anywhere.
Remove it.

Change-Id: I0d719b4ac90b69989a38fdd85c3f006e0669a3d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/04/83104/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <section xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0" xml:id="addmethod.openstackapi"> <title>Addmethod.Openstackapi</title> <section xml:id="header"> <title>Header</title> <para> .. Copyright 2010-2011 OpenStack Foundation All Rights Reserved. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. </para> </section> <section xml:id="Adding-a-Method-to-the-OpenStack-API"> <title>Adding-A-Method-To-The-Openstack-Api</title> <para> ==================================== The interface is a mostly RESTful API. REST stands for Representational State Transfer and provides an architecture "style" for distributed systems using HTTP for transport. Figure out a way to express your request and response in terms of resources that are being created, modified, read, or destroyed. </para> </section> <section xml:id="Routing"> <title>Routing</title> <para> ------- To map URLs to controllers+actions, OpenStack uses the Routes package, a clone of Rails routes for Python implementations. See http://routes.groovie.org/ for more information. URLs are mapped to "action" methods on "controller" classes in ``cinder/api/openstack/__init__/ApiRouter.__init__`` . See http://routes.groovie.org/manual.html for all syntax, but you'll probably just need these two: - mapper.connect() lets you map a single URL to a single action on a controller. - mapper.resource() connects many standard URLs to actions on a controller. </para> </section> <section xml:id="Controllers-and-actions"> <title>Controllers-And-Actions</title> <para> ----------------------- Controllers live in ``cinder/api/openstack``, and inherit from cinder.wsgi.Controller. See ``cinder/api/openstack/servers.py`` for an example. Action methods take parameters that are sucked out of the URL by mapper.connect() or .resource(). The first two parameters are self and the WebOb request, from which you can get the req.environ, req.body, req.headers, etc. </para> </section> <section xml:id="Serialization"> <title>Serialization</title> <para> ------------- Actions return a dictionary, and wsgi.Controller serializes that to JSON or XML based on the request's content-type. If you define a new controller, you'll need to define a ``_serialization_metadata`` attribute on the class, to tell wsgi.Controller how to convert your dictionary to XML. It needs to know the singular form of any list tag such as ``[servers]`` list contains ``[server]`` tags, and which dictionary keys are to be XML attributes as opposed to subtags such as ``[server id="4"/]`` instead of ``[server][id]4[/id][/server]``. See `cinder/api/openstack/servers.py` for an example. Faults ------ If you need to return a non-200, you should return faults.Fault(webob.exc.HTTPNotFound()) </para> </section> </section>

commit_message:
do not create radosgw region map in post-deploy

RadosGW region map may intermittently get corrupted when it is created
during post-deployment, leading to RadosGW being unable to start.

Change-Id: I9587b983ad50d74d22eb157b5d98a6f709e58b23
Related-bug: #1287166

commit_message:
Change NOVA_VIF_DRIVER for ml2 with NeutronFirewallVIFDriver

In Icehouse, Neturon + OVS + Nova + Iptables based security group
is broken. As a workaround fix, we introduced NeturonFirewallVIFDriver.
In this commit, we will apply this as a defualt for ML2 plugin

This is nova side related fix
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/82904/

Change-Id: I45f9b4652bae6b47ff4b01007ad0d97f1e12e1ae
Related-bug: 1297469

commit_message:
multi backends: factorize code between single and multi backends

Code is duplicated between single volume backend
(cinder::volume::*) and multi backends (cinder::backend::*).
This commits updates the single volume backends to make use
of the respective multiple backends classes.

Change-Id: I26a796fb6131fa469f007af54cb96b3605c0f74d

commit_message:
Revises text to explain that multiple passwords are needed

Change-Id: I502c3b9f5789eb5452b486407cc362c6ff95a29b
Closes-bug: 1296213
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/22/82622/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <title>Passwords</title> <para>The various OpenStack services and the required software like the database and the Messaging server have to be password protected. You use these passwords when configuring a service and then again to access the service. You have to choose a random password while configuring the service and later remember to use the same password when accessing it. Optionally, you can generate passwords with the <application>pwgen</application> program to generate a random string of letters and numbers to create passwords. Or, to create passwords one at a time, use the output of this command repeatedly: <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>openssl rand -hex 10</userinput></screen>
deleted_lines: <title>Passwords</title> <para>The various OpenStack services and the required software like the database and the Messaging server have to be password protected. These passwords are needed when configuring a service and then again to access the service. You have to choose a random password while configuring the service and later remember to use the same password when accessing it. To generate a list of passwords, you can use the <application>pwgen</application> program to generate a list of passwords or take the output of: <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>openssl rand -hex 10</userinput></screen>

commit_message:
Don't attempt to fill faults for instance_list if FlavorNotFound

When getting a list of servers with details, if a FlavorNotFound is
raised from the compute API the local instance_list variable is set to
an empty list, but later instance_list.fill_faults() is called on it
assuming it is an InstanceList object, which will cause an
AttributeError.

This patch just checks to see if instance_list is empty before calling
fill_faults since InstanceList.fill_faults assumes the list is not empty
when called, so it's not trivial to simply create an empty InstanceList
here and set it to the instance_list variable.

The new test cases use testtools.matchers.HasLength and while seeing
if testtools was imported I noticed it (along with mox) was in the
wrong import group, so also fixed the order there.

This patch also fixes the test_get_server_details_empty unit test to
actually call the detail method rather than index.

Closes-Bug: #1296940

Change-Id: I9f85c2a0b70f41e5bba2da05a2339caf2a8efc3e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/82607/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Catch InstanceNotFound exceptions for V2 API floating_ips

Adds handling of InstanceNotFound exceptions in the V2 API
floating_ips extension and translate them to HTTPNotFound rather
than letting them propogate and causing a traceback in the logs

Co-Authored-By: Michael Still <mikal@stillhq.com>

Change-Id: Idc1a5b2e6b8cb9778d032e5e1fc8112a65fc225c
Closes-Bug: 1271047

commit_message:
Avoid using .values() on the indexed columns

The length of a dict-like object should be the same as the length of the
list of values in the object, so calling .values() should be unnecessary
here.

Change-Id: I625dc7dea00cc8f09c68ea104c5c64c5f39fffc0
Closes-Bug: 1297059

commit_message:
SQLAlchemy requirements put in order

- require SQLAlchemy>=0.7.8 if no stricter requirement present;
- allow SQLAlhchemy 0.9.x in python 3.3 and pypy test environments.

Change-Id: I8ee29c66612e8051a26a1633c0973d0dfa048fc4

commit_message:
Fix wait_for_tarball 'None' error

Due to delays in the prerelease queue, wait_for_tarball would sometimes
shortcircuit and return 'None' jobs, or timeout completely. This fixes
both issues.

Change-Id: Iac054a2b22d8db1cf0d543c8ac0fdf432ea08490

commit_message:
Use same code to reset flow and parts of it

Instead of having special engine and storage method to reset
reverted flow when running it again, delegate the job to
graph action, which already does almost same thing when retrying
subgraphs.

Change-Id: Icf257cfc0fb161ab2199baa3d7c7e64664a109e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/25/82825/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Optimize dependency links in flattening

With this change a link between two subflows caused by task dependency
does not impose execution ordering between all tasks of that subflows
any more: only provider and consumer of the dependency are now linked.
For some cases this is a major optimization, as it allows more
independent parts of the flow to be executed or reverted in parallel. It
also allows, for example, converting parts of flow into subflows without
loosing performance.

Because with this change parts of parent flow that depend on some tasks
in subflow can be executed before all tasks in the subflow are
completed, graph analyzer is changed to not stop at subflow border when
iterating subgraphs.

Change-Id: I45587a4e851febe3c43cfa7b74bdfc50f61e0279

commit_message:
Catch InstanceNotFound exceptions for V2 API deferred delete

Adds handling of InstanceNotFound exceptions in the V2 API
deferred delete and translate them to HTTPNotFound rather
than letting them propagate up causing a traceback in the
nova log.

Co-Authored-By: Michael Still <mikal@stillhq.com>

Change-Id: I3d434f28313ae633bdcb9cef82a7b8b0020b5722
Closes-Bug: 1270803

commit_message:
Run worker-based engine tests faster

This change reduces polling intervals for transport and proxy
from default 1 second to 0.01 second. On my machine this reduces
time needed to run WorkerBasedEngineTest almost 5 times, which,
in turn, makes testr almost twice faster.

Change-Id: I8dfe08c06234f33e838059b2f8d9d6a7c7819e06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/69/83069/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add service name to service catalog

This should have always been a part of the catalog but was overlooked in
implementation. Make sure it is correctly defined in the spec to prevent
it happening again.

Closes-Bug: #1288098
Change-Id: I4184ae663ea06ddef924f07b881759bcae211da8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/identity-api refs/changes/75/81975/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - Addition of `name` optional variable to be included from service definition into the service catalog. - Include `region_id` in service catalog in line with `region` deprecation from endpoint definition. "name": "--service-name--", Required attributes for the service object are: - `id`: the service entity id. - `type`: Describes the API implemented by the service. Optional attributes for the service object are: - `name`: User-facing name of the service. *New in version 3.3* Required attributes for the endpoint object are: - `id`: The endpoint entity id. - `interface`: The visibility of the endpoint. Should be one of `public`, `internal` or `admin`. - `url`: Fully qualified URL of the service endpoint. Optional attributes for the service object are: - `region`: The geographic location of the service endpoint. **Deprecated in version 3.3** - `region_id`: The region identifier of the service endpoint. **New in version 3.3** "type": "identity", "name": "keystone" "type": "identity", "name": "keystone"

commit_message:
Sanitize set passed to dumps()

Datatype set is not parseable by json.dumps() and will cause
ValueError. Catching that in _sanitizer and converting to list.

Implements tag operations add, replace and remove to glance/api/v2/images.py

glance image-update --tags <tags> <Image ID> did not work due the
serialization issue and the operations missing. This will fix image-update
--tags.

Closes-Bug: #1296589

Change-Id: Ide7351632eb7b3748d3fa143d55faf66af5aa1e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/12/83112/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if path_root == 'tags': self._do_replace_tags(image, value) if path_root == 'tags': self._do_add_tags(image, value) if path_root == 'tags': self._do_remove_tags(image, path[1]) def _do_replace_tags(self, image, value): for tag in range(len(image.tags)): self._do_remove_tags(image, tag) self._do_add_tags(image, value) def _do_add_tags(self, image, value): try: image.tags.add(value) except exception.NotFound as e: raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound(explanation=e.msg) except exception.Forbidden as e: raise webob.exc.HTTPForbidden(explanation=e.msg) except exception.ImageTagLimitExceeded as e: raise webob.exc.HTTPRequestEntityTooLarge(explanation=e.msg) def _do_remove_tags(self, image, pos): LOG.debug(_(image.tags)) try: image.tags.remove(list(image.tags)[int(pos)]) except exception.NotFound as e: raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound(explanation=e.msg) except exception.Forbidden as e: raise webob.exc.HTTPForbidden(explanation=e.msg) _path_depth_limits = {'locations': {'add': 2, 'remove': 2, 'replace': 1}, 'tags': {'add': 2, 'remove': 2, 'replace': 2}} # image's 'tags' list at last.

commit_message:
[IDH] Fixed cluster scale down

There were two problems:
1. Datanoded status started to return node without domain
2. Wrong services were used to get processes status

Change-Id: I34da2e36328f22fff9636aac9729887dd8fd94ce
Closes-Bug: #1289055

commit_message:
Adjust the exception hierachy

Group the exceptions into the following groups
  * Storage
  * Jobs
  * Execution
  * Other (wrapped failure here)

This grouping makes it easier to understand where
one type of exception should be used vs using another
type of exception.

Backwards incompatible changes:
  * StorageError -> StorageFailure
  * AlreadyExists -> Duplicate
  * WrappedFailure now inherits from Exception
    and not directly from TaskFlowException since it
    wraps arbitrary other exceptions and is not
    specific to taskflow.

Cleanups:
  * JobNotFound -> NotFound
  * EmptyFlow -> Empty
  * JobAlreadyExists -> AlreadyExists
  * InvariantViolation (X)
  * ConnectionFailure (X)

Change-Id: I0e1e81b513fbbc7adb8bfaa1244993e345ab70d3

commit_message:
Revive Alembic-based database migration logic.

Alembic migrations were introduced to Barbican a while ago but have not been
used recently. This CR revisits the migration logic and ensures that time-zero
database tables creation is distinguished from Alembic-base schema updates.
The associated database migration script is also revived, allowing for
schema migrations outside of the Barbican boot process.

Change-Id: I3e7fd7ac3f629da18329c22ad11cb9ccc1b7f9f9
Implements: blueprint db-revive-migrations

Add unit test to check the order of Qpid hosts on reconnect

Change-Id: I32e20c0e747e6489dab4b0358d422b8a9c6b982e
Partial-Bug: 1261631
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/61/81261/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mockclass TestQpidReconnectOrder(test_utils.BaseTestCase): """Unit Test cases to test reconnection """ def setUp(self): super(TestQpidReconnectOrder, self).setUp() self.conf.register_opts(qpid_driver.qpid_opts) def tearDown(self): self.conf.unregister_opts(qpid_driver.qpid_opts) super(TestQpidReconnectOrder, self).tearDown() def test_reconnect_order(self): brokers = ('host1', 'host2', 'host3', 'host4', 'host5') brokers_count = len(brokers) info = {'attempt': 0} class MyConnection(qpid_driver.Connection): def connection_create(myself, broker): super(MyConnection, myself).connection_create(broker) expected_broker = brokers[info['attempt'] % brokers_count] self.assertEqual(broker, expected_broker) info['attempt'] += 1 self.stubs.Set(qpid_driver, 'Connection', MyConnection) self.config(qpid_hosts=brokers) with mock.patch('qpid.messaging.Connection'): # starting from the first broker in the list connection = qpid_driver.Connection(self.conf) # reconnect will advance to the next broker, one broker per # attempt, and then wrap to the start of the list once the end is # reached for _ in range(brokers_count): connection.reconnect() connection.close()

subject: Add tests.d to cache-url
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-25 22:56:44.000000000', 'files': ['elements/cache-url/tests.d/01-test-deps', 'elements/cache-url/tests.d/.testr.conf', 'elements/cache-url/tests.d/10-test-cache-url'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/e604d8ab779f7610c90233ab9112e7f4185a4d66', 'message': "Add tests.d to cache-url

This is a trivial case since the element consists of only
one script, and as noted inline one of the tests probably needs
to be moved into a unit test suite, but hopefully this shows where
I'm headed with the tests.d feature.

Change-Id: I951d5e0c5b7c06f8640ddb9594b9835720bad0ed
"}]
commit_message:
Add tests.d to cache-url

This is a trivial case since the element consists of only
one script, and as noted inline one of the tests probably needs
to be moved into a unit test suite, but hopefully this shows where
I'm headed with the tests.d feature.

Change-Id: I951d5e0c5b7c06f8640ddb9594b9835720bad0ed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/40/82940/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python import os import subprocess import tempfile import unittest from oslotest import base # This is the diskimage-builder README.md file from the 0.1.9 tag, so it # shouldn't be changing in the future. TEST_FILE = ('http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/diskimage-builder/' 'tree/README.md?id=94805549d87c9610a7ddfdcd8ee9264d0740782c') class TestCacheUrl(base.BaseTestCase): def test_cache_url_exists(self): self.assertTrue(os.path.exists('/usr/local/bin/cache-url')) # This should maybe be an actual unit test so we don't have to wait for # an entire image build to verify the behavior... def test_cache_url_caches(self): tempdir = tempfile.mkdtemp() temppath = os.path.join(tempdir, 'README.md') subprocess.call(['/usr/local/bin/cache-url', TEST_FILE, temppath]) self.assertTrue(os.path.exists(temppath)) modification_time = os.path.getmtime(temppath) subprocess.call(['/usr/local/bin/cache-url', TEST_FILE, temppath]) self.assertEqual(modification_time, os.path.getmtime(temppath)) if __name__ == '__main__': unittest.main()

commit_message:
POC: Add ability to run test scripts

This adds a tests.d target to disk-image-create that allows some
verification of image build behavior.  See the follow-up commit
for a rough POC of doing so.  This target will only be run if
-t is passed to disk-image-create, so it shouldn't affect
production image builds.

I haven't entirely nailed down how I think this should work,
but I thought I'd push what I have and see what everyone else
thinks.

Some concerns I have:
-It takes a relatively long time to build even a simple image,
 which means iterating on these tests is time-consuming
-I'm not sure how this fits into our Jenkins workflow.  I've had
 the thought that maybe we run an image build for every changed
 element in a dib commit, but I'm unsure whether that's even
 possible for all of them.  Some of them may not be sane to use
 standalone.  Maybe could be resolved with a test-deps file?  Also,
 that wouldn't address element dependencies where a change in one
 breaks another.
-While writing the followup change I realized that one of the tests
 I wrote is more of a unit test for a script than something that
 needs to be run at build time.  We probably need to also set up
 actual unit tests for this project.  I think there will still be
 some value to being able to assert things about a final image
 though, so I don't think that would replace this entirely.

Change-Id: Ibd0d7081298ef010ac1b73761e030c1c305b3bd7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/39/82939/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: TEMP=`getopt -o a:ho:xucntp: -l no-tmpfs,offline,help,min-tmpfs:,image-size:,image-cache:,max-online-resize: -n $SCRIPTNAME -- "$@"` -t) shift; RUN_TESTS="True";;if [ $RUN_TESTS == "True" ]; then run_d_in_target tests fi

commit_message:
Return 405 when attempting DELETE on /tasks

We currently return 404 NotFound when attempting to delete a task
by hitting the resource /v2/tasks/{task_id}. However, as this
resource exists and we do not allow DELETE on tasks, the correct
response is 405 MethodNotAllowed.

Implementing as per spec on
http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html

Fixes bug 1287951

Change-Id: Ia4a969e595b520dbc5f4e9a463d967681465ae6f

commit_message:
Add documentation for EMC VNX Direct Driver.

This patch addes documentation for EMC VNX Direct Driver.

Closes-Bug: #1296201

Change-Id: I832585fa139c4d98b0a72c24881869ad7cd9eab3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/32/82332/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <section xml:id="emc-vnx-direct-driver" xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0"> <?dbhtml stop-chunking?> <title>EMC VNX direct driver</title> <para>The EMC VNX direct driver is based on the <literal> ISCSIDriver</literal> defined in Cinder, with the ability to create/delete and attach/detach volumes and create/delete snapshots, and so on.</para> <para>The driver executes the volume operations by communicating with the backend EMC VNX storage through NaviSec CLI. </para> <section xml:id="emc-reqs"> <title>System requirements</title> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>Flare version 5.32 or higher.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>VNX Snapshot and Clone license must be activated for the array. All the iSCSI ports from the VNX should be accessible via OpenStack hosts.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Navisphere CLI v7.32 or higher</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <para>EMC storage VNX Series are supported.</para> </section> <section xml:id="emc-supported-ops"> <title>Supported operations</title> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>Create volume</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Delete volume</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Attach volume</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Detach volume</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Create snapshot</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Delete snapshot</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Create volume from snapshot</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Create cloned volume</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Copy image to volume</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Copy volume to image</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Extend volume</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> </section> <section xml:id="emc-prep"> <title>How to set up the VNX direct driver</title> <procedure> <title>Install NaviSecCLI</title> <step> <para>NaviSecCLI tool needs to be installed on the controller node and all the Cinder nodes in an OpenStack deployment. See <xref linkend="install-naviseccli"/>.</para> </step> <step> <para>Register with VNX. See <xref linkend="register-vnx-iscsi"/> </para> </step> </procedure> <section xml:id="install-naviseccli"> <title>Install NaviSecCLI</title> <para>Download the NaviSecCLI installer from EMC's Website at <link xlink:href="https://support.emc.com/ downloads/5890_Navisphere-Agents-CLI---Linux">, and install as follows:</para> <para>On Ubuntu x64:</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para><screen>Create directory /opt/Navisphere/bin/ <prompt>#</prompt><userinput>mkdir -f /opt/Navisphere/bin/ </userinput></screen></para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Copy the RPM package in the above created directory. </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><screen><prompt>#</prompt><userinput> cd /opt/Navisphere/bin/</userinput></screen></para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><screen><prompt>#</prompt><userinput> sudo apt-get install alien -y </userinput></screen></para> </listitem> <listitem> <para><screen><prompt>#</prompt><userinput> sudo alien -i NaviCLI-Linux-64-x86-en_US-7.xx.xx.x.xx.x86_64.rpm </userinput></screen></para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <para>For all the other variants of Linux, install the rpm as usual. </para> </section> <section xml:id="register-vnx-iscsi"> <title>Register with VNX</title> <para>To export a VNX volume to a compute node or cinder volume node, you must register the node with VNX.</para> <procedure> <title>Register the node</title> <step><para>On the compute node or cinder volume node <literal>1.1.1.1</literal>, do the following (assume <literal>10.10.61.35</literal> is the iscsi target):</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>/etc/init.d/open-iscsi start</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>iscsiadm -m discovery -t st -p 10.10.61.35</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>cd /etc/iscsi</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>sudo more initiatorname.iscsi</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>iscsiadm -m node</userinput></screen></step> <step><para>Log in to VNX from the compute node using the target corresponding to the SPA port:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>iscsiadm -m node -T iqn.1992-04.com.emc:cx.apm01234567890.a0 -p 10.10.61.35 -l</userinput></screen> <para>Where <literal>iqn.1992-04.com.emc:cx.apm01234567890.a0</literal> is the initiator name of the compute node. Login to Unisphere, go to <literal>VNX00000</literal>->Hosts->Initiators, Refresh and wait until initiator <literal>iqn.1992-04.com.emc:cx.apm01234567890.a0</literal> with SP Port <literal>A-8v0</literal> appears.</para></step> <step><para>Click the <guibutton>Register</guibutton> button, select <guilabel>CLARiiON/VNX</guilabel>, and enter the host name <literal>myhost1</literal> and IP address <literal>myhost1</literal>. Click <guibutton>Register</guibutton>. Now host <literal>1.1.1.1</literal> also appears under Hosts->Host List.</para></step> <step><para>Log out of VNX on the compute node:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>iscsiadm -m node -u</userinput></screen></step> <step> <para>Log in to VNX from the compute node using the target corresponding to the SPB port:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>iscsiadm -m node -T iqn.1992-04.com.emc:cx.apm01234567890.b8 -p 10.10.10.11 -l</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>In Unisphere register the initiator with the SPB port.</para></step> <step><para>Log out:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>iscsiadm -m node -u</userinput></screen></step> </procedure> </section> <section xml:id="emc-config-file"> <title><filename>cinder.conf</filename> configuration file</title> <para>Make the following changes in <filename>/etc/cinder/cinder.conf</filename>.</para> <para>For VNX iSCSI driver, add the following entries, where <literal>10.10.61.35</literal> is the IP address of the VNX iSCSI target, <literal>10.10.72.41</literal> is the IP address of the VNX array, <systemitem>default_timeout</systemitem> is the default time out for CLI operations in minutes, and <systemitem>max_luns_per_storage_group</systemitem> is the default max number of LUNs in a storage group:</para> <programlisting language="ini"> iscsi_ip_address = 10.10.61.35 san_ip = 10.10.72.41 san_login = username san_password = password naviseccli_path = /opt/Navisphere/bin/naviseccli storage_vnx_pool_name = poolname default_timeout = 10 max_luns_per_storage_group=256 volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.emc.emc_cli_iscsi.EMCCLIISCSIDriver </programlisting> <para>Restart the <systemitem class="service" >cinder-volume</systemitem> service.</para> </section> <section xml:id="emc-volume-type"> <title>Volume type support</title> <para>Volume type support allows user to choose thick/thin provisioning capabilities.</para> <para>Here is an example of how to setup volume type. First create volume types. Then define extra specs for each volume type.</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt><userinput>cinder --os-username admin --os-tenant-name admin type-create "TypeA"</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt><userinput>cinder --os-username admin --os-tenant-name admin type-create "TypeB"</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt><userinput>cinder --os-username admin --os-tenant-name admin type-key "TypeA" set storagetype:provisioning=thick</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt><userinput>cinder --os-username admin --os-tenant-name admin type-key "TypeB" set storagetype:provisioning=thin</userinput></screen> <para>In the above example, two volume types are created. They are "TypeA" and "TypeB". For TypeA, "storagetype:provisioning" is set to "thick". Similarly for TypeB, "storagetype:provisioning" is set to "thin". If "storagetype:provisioning" is not specified, it will be default to thick.</para> </section> </section> </section>

commit_message:
Apply service name conventions for Image Service

There are several instances of "Image service" in the upstream
documentation. As was recently clarified in the docs mailing list,
these should be "Image Service". This patch applies the fix.

Change-Id: Iefb63673162ae97b2c0fe1c3ff3fb1ac05e95d83
Partial-Bug: #1217503

commit_message:
Apply service name conventions for Block Storage

There are several instances of "Block Storage Service" in the
upstream documentation. As was recently clarified in the docs
mailing list, these should be "Block Storage service". This patch
applies the fix.

Change-Id: I591c100ab031b75f1c0d27d45f53e32401a26e30
Partial-Bug: #1217503

commit_message:
Generalize control_exchange attribute

The control exchange attribute was placed under 'rabbit' but it is
actually a property for 'qpid' too so moved it out at the same level as
the related 'rpc_backend'. Also moved it closer to rpc_backend in the
template.

Documented both attributes.

Change-Id: Iade5a48abbb865cf3a21c9beb8e6cc7783517fb0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-block-storage refs/changes/46/81946/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * `openstack["block-storage"]["control_exchange"]` - The AMQP exchange to connect to if using RabbitMQ or Qpid, defaults to cinder * `openstack["block-storage"]["rpc_backend"]` - The messaging module to use, defaults to kombu.

Adds specs for template contents

pending tests have been addressed, one in spec/compute_spec.rb that
was tied to a cookbook_file resource has been just removed.
